metadata.case_name: Commissioner of Income Tax / Excess Profits Tax v. M/s. N. M. Rayaloo Iyer Sons

facts.text: M/s. N. M. Rayaloo Iyer Sons are a firm carrying on business principally in dyes and chemicals as chief representatives in South India of products of Imperial Chemical Industries (India) Ltd. (I.C.I.), conducted under name Colours Trading Company with head office at Madura and thirteen branches.
Business originally in partnership by three brothers: N. M. R. Venkatakrishna Iyer, N. M. R. Subbaraman and N. M. R. Krishnamurti.
On April 13, 1946, N. M. R. Subbaraman retired and share of N. M. R. Venkatakrishna Iyer taken over by N. M. R. Venkatakrishna Iyer Sons Ltd., but business continued in original name.
N. M. R. Mahadevan (son of N. M. R. Venkatakrishna Iyer) employed as General Manager of Colours Trading Co.

By letter dated April 17, 1940, assessees agreed to pay Mahadevan Rs. 1,800 per annum and 5% of net profits of Colours Trading Company (gross profits minus salaries, wages, other outgoings, no capital deduction).
By letter dated March 30, 1943, Mahadevan's salary fixed at Rs. 3,000 per annum and commission enhanced to 12% of net profits.
Branch offices managed by local managers and assistant managers paid monthly salary, annual and special bonus, dearness allowance.

Assessees received commission from I.C.I. at 7-12% on different products; from April 1, 1944, special emergency commission of 5% on dyes and dyestuffs, increased to 15% from March 1, 1945, reduced to 10% from September 1, 1946.

Appeals relate to excess profits tax for periods ending April 13, 1943; April 12, 1944; April 12, 1945; March 31, 1946; and business profits tax for periods ending April 12, 1946; March 31, 1947; April 13, 1947; March 31, 1948; April 12, 1948.
Assessees claimed payments to employees (1942-43 to 1947-48) of share in special emergency commission from I.C.I., in addition to salary, dearness allowance, bonuses.
I.C.I. letter January 24, 1944 recommended 1% out of 5% emergency commission to sub-distributors; assessees paid employees 1.5-4%. Later, for 15%, recommended 6%, assessees paid 2-7.5% up to 12%.
Commission payable only if dyes turnover exceeded Rs. 1,00,000 net per year, but paid even when short.

Year ending April 12, 1945: revision of salaries, dearness allowance and special bonus exceeding 50% of basic salary, plus annual bonus equal to salary; total at least 2 times basic; plus commission exceeding 12 times basic in some cases.
Income-tax Officer disallowed 12.5% to Mahadevan for 1943-44, 1944-45; and commissions to branch managers/employees for 1945-46 to 1948-49.
Appellate Assistant Commissioner allowed 5% or 12.5% post-tax (higher) to Mahadevan, confirmed by Tribunal; disallowed employee commissions.
Tribunal referred questions to High Court under s.66(1) Income Tax Act r/w s.21 Excess Profits Tax Act.

Questions in Referred Case No. 44 of 1953: (1) Whether ITO precluded from examining if payment wholly/exclusively for business under s.10(2)(xv); (2) Material for Tribunal holding Mahadevan commission not wholly/exclusively; (3) Whether employee commissions wholly/exclusively for business.

Questions in Referred Case No. 53 of 1952: (1) Whether EPT deductible before Mahadevan 12.5% commission; (2) Material for unreasonableness under rule 12 Sch 1 EPT Act; (3) Justification for disallowing branch managers commission under rule 12.
High Court held deductions under s.10(2)(x) not (2)(xv); for Mahadevan, no EPT deduction before commission; for employees, allowed after supplementary statement, finding no unreasonableness.
Emergency commission received and paid: 1945-46: Rs.1,28,533 rec, Rs.1,00,715 paid; 1946-47: Rs.3,20,391 rec, Rs.2,44,698 paid; etc.
Specific high payments: Themaswamy commission Rs.15k-23k on Rs.2100 salary; others similar excesses.
EPT Officer findings: employees amply remunerated; no demand for increase; commission credited not paid; agreements fabricated; not for business.

legal_issues.text: Whether in computing net profits for Mahadevan's 12.5% commission, excess profits tax is deductible before calculation.
Whether commission payments to Mahadevan and employees are deductible under s.10(2)(xv) or s.10(2)(x) Income-tax Act, and reasonable under rule 12 Sch 1 Excess Profits Tax Act.
Whether Tribunal had material to hold commissions not wholly and exclusively for business or unreasonable.

petitioner_arguments.text: Commission to Mahadevan should be after deducting excess profits tax as per commercial accountancy and agreement interpretation; net profits mean divisible profits post-tax.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Agreement dated 17-4-1940 and 30-3-1943; Commissioner of Income-tax v. Delhi Flour Mills Co. Ltd.

petitioner_arguments.text: Employee commissions not reasonable or necessary under rule 12 Sch 1 EPT Act; employees already generously paid; payments disproportionate, possibly to dissipate profits; no sub-distributors; paid despite low turnover; agreements suspect.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Rule 12 Sch 1 Excess Profits Tax Act; s.10(2)(x) Income-tax Act

respondent_arguments.text: Payments shared emergency commission as recommended by I.C.I. to maintain reputation amid black-marketing; reasonable from businessman's view; within I.C.I. percentages; windfall shared with employees.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s.10(2)(x) Income-tax Act; rule 12 Sch 1 EPT Act; commercial expediency

respondent_arguments.text: Minima by I.C.I. not absolute standard; payments necessary for business in disturbed conditions.

court_reasoning.text: Agreement for Mahadevan: 'outgoings' includes excess profits tax; no indication to exclude; net profits not divisible post-tax per Delhi Flour Mills.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Expression 'outgoings' not restricted to business outgoings only.

court_reasoning.text: Deductions for employee commissions permissible under s.10(2)(x) IT Act for income-tax; for EPT, subject to rule 12 Sch 1 reasonableness and necessity by EPT Officer/Tribunal.
court_reasoning.key_observation: EPT Officer/Tribunal to decide reasonableness objectively; High Court advisory, cannot reappraise evidence.

court_reasoning.text: EPT Officer/Tribunal had ample material: generous salaries/bonuses, disproportionate commissions, low turnover payments, no sub-distributors need; conclusion not perverse.
court_reasoning.key_observation: High Court erred in substituting view; must leave to taxing authorities.

holdings.text: Excess profits tax deductible before computing Mahadevan's commission? No, as per agreement interpretation.
Disallowance of employee commissions justified under rule 12 Sch 1 EPT Act.
High Court cannot interfere with Tribunal's factual findings on reasonableness unless error of law.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, Delhi v. Delhi Flour Mills Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: High Court followed on no EPT deduction before net profits; SC holds otherwise on agreement construction.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Delhi Flour Mills Co. Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Net profits mean divisible profits after EPT deduction in similar agreement.

statutes_cited.name: Income-tax Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Deduction for payments wholly/exclusively for business; specific for commission/bonus to employees.

statutes_cited.name: Excess Profits Tax Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Applies IT Act s.10 with modifications; no deduction for unreasonable expenses; prior Commissioner approval.

statutes_cited.name: Business Profits Tax Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Supersedes EPT Act; similar provisions on profits computation and reasonableness.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court allowed Appeal No. 494 of 1958, holding that disallowance of commissions to branch managers and employees was justified under rule 12 Sch 1 of Excess Profits Tax Act; reversed High Court; no order as to costs.
outcome.relief_granted: Reversal of High Court order allowing deductions for employee commissions in excess profits tax/business profits tax assessments.

key_quotes.text: "The jurisdiction which the High Court exercises on questions referred to it under the E. P. T. Act is merely advisory the High Court is not sitting in appeal over the judgment of the taxing authorities."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines limits of High Court's role in tax references.

key_quotes.text: "Profits of a business for purposes of Excess Profits Tax Act have to be ascertained by reference to section 10 of the Income-tax Act modified to the extent directed by Schedule 1 of the Excess Profits Tax Act."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "It is for him [EPT Officer] subject to review by the Tribunal to decide whether the deduction is reasonable and necessary, having regard to the requirements of the business."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Primary duty on taxing authorities for reasonableness.
